page.title: 09Farming 4: Buildings/Selling
page.content: Even though the winters are very harsh on the Downs, the cattle and sheep are kept warm. In very bitter winters snow often covers the pastures. In this weather the sheeps or cows are put in sheds and given bales of hay for bedding and food. As the farms can have no silage, hay is sparse during the winter. The oats and barley that is grown is all sold off at the corn exchange. Even though Britain has much corn, it needs harder grain to make bread than is grown here. At the exchange the corn is bought by the big companies. Most of the dairy products are also sold to these companies. The few calves that are reared for beef are sold at markets. As the grazing where the sheep are kept is rough, the sheep are kept for wool rather than mutton. The sheep are also sold at market.
